title: Australia coach Michael Cheika drops F-bomb and reacts badly after England defeat
text:
There are huge question marks over Cheika’s future after Saturday’s loss to England (Picture: Getty)

Australia coach Michael Cheika asked reporters to ‘think about his feelings’ during his post-match press conference after England knocked them out of the Rugby World Cup.

Jonny May scored twice as England thrashed Australia 40-16 in Oita on Saturday to set up a semi-final clash with either Ireland or New Zealand.

Australia, meanwhile, will fly home after their worst World Cup result in 12 years and Cheika will have to answer questions over his persistent selection reshuffling.

He has often said that a failure to win the tournament would see him walk away from the job as Australia coach but when quizzed over his own future after losing to England, he refused to answer the question.

‘It’s a cruel, cruel world when you’re asking those questions two minutes after being knocked out of a World Cup,’ Cheika said.

‘If you can find it in your heart, ask the relevant questions. Show a little more compassion for someone who is hurting. Think about someone’s feelings and just chill.’

Cheika had already given a dejected interview to the official broadcaster pitchside after the defeat and dropped the F-bomb when talking about letting down the fans who had travelled out to Japan.

🗣 "The better team won. I was supposed to get this done for the people here and for Australians. I'm so disappointed." @wallabies' Michael Cheika reflects on his side's loss tonight #RWC2019 #ENGvAUS #RWCOita pic.twitter.com/f0T2IevFXr — Rugby World Cup (@rugbyworldcup) October 19, 2019

‘The better team won, that’s the way it is. You’ve got suck that up some times,’ he said.

‘But I was supposed to get this done for the people here, for Australians, I’m f***ing so disappointed.’

Cheika was emotional immediately after his side’s exit from the Rugby World Cup (Picture: Getty)

Australia started Christian Lealiifano at fly-half against England but had also included Bernard Foley and Matt Toomua at No 10 during the tournament, just one example of the different variations Cheika opted for.

But the one constant was the Wallabies style of playing, running the ball wherever possible, something for which the coach refused to apologise.

‘That’s how we play. That’s the way we play footy,’ Cheika added. ‘We’re not going to go to a kick and defend game. We’d rather win our way or no way. That’s the way Aussies want us to play.’
